title: It's time to end the energy debate blame game
text:
Flow on problems, particularly the increasing need for frequency control and inertia across the energy system in this brave new world – previously these services were provided by coal-fired plants – are other points of unity.

But as Tanna says, the sector’s ability to solve these clear problems has been made difficult by the rhetoric used by all sides.

“Energy is stuck,” Tanna told the summit. “Everyone is shouting – and everyone is right, because everyone is talking about different things. It’s like being in a bar just before closing time.

“If we’re to get anywhere, this tribalism and pursuit of people to blame must stop.”

Tanna’s top-level call is for what she describes as a “thoughtful transition” that plays to the strength of both coal-fired power and renewable energy, recognising the need to encourage investment so the inevitable retirement of a dozen coal-fired plants in the next three decades is managed carefully and the necessary firming power required to support intermittent renewables is developed in way that is affordable and simple for customers.

Nothing in that seems very controversial.

But Tanna’s five-point plan to deliver this underscores how the tone of the debate has got in the way.

Advertisement

Her plan calls for: The government needs to drop its “big stick” rhetoric; the sector needs to commit to a national energy framework; the right signals need to be sent to encourage the private sector to invest the estimated $400 billion needed to fund the transition; state government bans on gas development must be lifted; and independent regulators should be left alone to do their jobs.

To Chanticleer’s untrained eye, Tanna’s point that tone is important is well made.

For example, it seemed that in his address to the summit, Taylor was unwilling to talk about the boom in renewable generation as a success of the Australian industry, instead positioning it as almost like a threat. Similarly, Victoria’s energy minister Lily D’Ambrosio seemed keen on Wednesday to paint coal-fire plants as old clunkers as she doubled down on her government’s target of delivering 50 per cent of its energy from renewable sources by 2030.

Neither position would seem helpful in finding solutions that benefit both consumers and the climate over the next few decades, which is surely where we need to be looking.

Australian Competition and Consumer Commission chairman Rod Sims, who also addressed the summit on Thursday, would say retailers such as EnergyAustralia brought no small part of this current rhetoric on itself, by, in his view, creating a deliberately confusing pricing environment that it could profit from.

Sims also said energy producers’ call for better market signals to encourage investment in firming power options such as fast-start gas peaking plants were also somewhat disingenuous. Are companies that are making a lot of money from high electricity prices really that keen to see prices fall, Sims asked.

This is a very fair question, although perhaps a short term issue.

Companies like EnergyAustralia know there’s a transition underway, and it will not stop. The fossil fuel plants they might profit from today will eventually be rendered useless; that’s why, as Tanna says, EnergyAustralia has one of the largest renewable energy portfolios in the country.

Tanna is right to call for a moderate, thoughtful tone to solve what are big and crucial problems. But as these challenges become more urgent, it seems the solutions get further away.
description: EnergyAustralia chief executive Catherine Tanna is right to call for a moderate, thoughtful tone to solve what are big and crucial problems. But as these challenges become more urgent, it seems the solutions get further away.
